File.Title: Efferent Projections of the Infralimbic Cortex of the Rat
File.Authors: KAREN M. HURLEY, HORST HERBERT, MARGARET M. MOGA,

Abstract.S: On the basis of stimulation studies, it has been proposed that the infralimbic cortex (ILC), Brodmann area 25, may serve as an autonomic motor cortex.

To explore this hypothesis, we have combined anterograde tracing with Phaseolus vulgaris leucoagglutinin (PHA-L) and retrograde tracing with wheat germ aggutinin conjugated to horseradish peroxidase (WGAHRP) to determine the efferent projections from the ILC.
Axons exit the ILC in one of three efferent pathways.
The dorsal pathway ascends through layers I11 and V to innervate the prelimbic and anterior cingulate cortices.
The lateral pathway courses through the nucleus accumbens to innervate the insular cortex, the perirhinal cortex, and parts of the piriform cortex.
In addition, some fibers from the lateral pathway enter the corticospinal tract.

The ventral pathway is by far the largest and innervates the thalamus (including the paraventricular nucleus of the thalamus, the border zone between the paraventricular and medial dorsal nuclei, and the paratenial, reuniens, ventromedial, parafasicular, and subparafasicular nuclei), the hypothalamus (including the lateral hypothalamic and medial preoptic areas, and the suprachiasmatic, dorsomedial, and supramammillary nuclei), the amygdala (including the central, medial, and basomedial nuclei, and the periamygdaloid cortex) and the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis.

The ventral efferent pathway also provides descending projections to autonomic cell groups of the brainstem and spinal cord including the periaqueductal gray matter, the parabrachial nucleus, the nucleus of the solitary tract, the dorsal motor vagal nucleus, the nucleus ambiguus, and the ventrolateral medulla, as well as lamina I and the intermediolateral column of the spinal cord.
The ILC has extensive projections to central autonomic nuclei that may subserve a role in modulating visceral responses to emotional stimuli, such as stress.

Introduction.S: It has been recognized since the 1940s that electrical stimulation of the medial prefrontal cortex can profoundly influence heart rate, blood pressure, and respiration (Smith, '45; Ward, '48; Kaada, '51; Wall and Davis, '51; Delgado, '60; Lofving, '61; for review see Cechetto and Saper, '90).

More recent studies have demonstrated that microstimulation of the perigenual cortical region, including the prelimbic and infralimbic (ILC) areas in the rat, can cause changes in gastric motility (Hurley-Gius and Neafsey, '86), heart rate, and respiration (Terreberry and Neafsey, '84; Burns and Wyss, '85; Hardy and Holmes, '88; Hurley et al., unpublished observations).

These observations, as well as the position of the ILC along the medial bank of the cerebral hemisphere opposite the insular (visceral sensory) cortex (Cechetto and Saper, '87), prompted Hurley-Gius and Neafsey ('86) to suggest that the ILC may function as a "visceral motor cortex."

This hypothesis is consistent with previously reported projections from the ILC to autonomic structures such as the lateral hypothalamus (Hosoya and Matsushita, '80), the parabrachial nucleus (Saper, '82a1, and the nucleus of the solitary tract (Ross et al., '81; van der Kooy et al., '82; Terreberry and Neafsey, '83), although direct innervation of autonomic motor nuclei has not been addressed, In addition, the ILC has been reported to send projections to a number of structures associated with the limbic system including the reuniens (Rose and Woosley, '48), ventromedial (Herkenham, '78), and mediodorsal (Groenewegen, 88) thalamic nuclei as well as the mamillary body (Allen and Hopkins, 87, 89).
To date, the only systematic study of ILC efferent projections was carried out in the cat by Room et al. ( 85) using the autoradiographic method.
However, injections used in this study were fairly large, encroaching upon the tenia tecta, and the caudal brainstem and spinal cord were not examined.

To examine systematically the efferent projectins from the ILC in the rat, we used small injections of the anterograde tracer Phaseolus vulgaris leucoagglutinin (PHA-L) into the medial prefrontal cortex, as well as injections of horseradish peroxidase conjugated to wheat germ agglutinin (WGA-HRP) into the ILC terminal fields to confirm their origins.

Methods.S: MATERIALS AND METHODS
Albino Sprague-Dawley rats (n = 104), weighing between 250 and 350 grams, were used in this study.
All animals were anesthetized with a 7% solution of chloral hydrate (350 mg/kg), fixed in a stereotaxic frame, and injections of the tracers were placed stereotaxically using glass micropipettes.
Anterograde transport experiments
In a series of 16 animals, PHA-L was iontophoresed into the ILC and adjacent areas using 5 FA pulses of positive current with a 7-second duty cycle for a period of 20 to 30 minutes.

After 7 to 14 days, the rats were deeply anesthetized and perfused transcardially with 100 ml of 0.9% saline followed by 250 ml of 4% paraformaldehyde-0.5% glutaraldehyde in 0.1 M phosphate buffer at pH 6.5 and an additional 250 ml of the same fixative at pH 8.5, and then 250 ml of 10% sucrose in 0.1 M phosphate buffer.
Brains were removed immediately and 50-krn coronal sections were cut on a freezing microtome.
Every section through the injection site and every third section through the rest of the brain was reacted immunohistochemically to visualize PHA-L.
The diluent used throughout the staining procedure was 3% normal swine serum (Pel-Freez) with 0.25% Triton-X 100 in phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) at pH 7.4.
The sections were incubated overnight in primary antiserum (goat anti-PHA-L, Vector Labs) diluted 1: 1,000.
Following thorough rinsing with PBS, the sections were incubated for 1 hour in a 150 dilution of swine antigoat IgG conjugated to horseradish peroxidase (Tago) and again rinsed with PBS.
In order to visualize the location of the HRP, the tissue was reacted with a filtered solution of 0.05% 3,3-diaminobenzidine in PBS to which 0.01% hydrogen peroxide was added.
The sections were rinsed in PBS, mounted onto gelatincoated slides, dehydrated through a graded series of alcohols, cleared in xylenes, and coverslipped using Histoclad mounting media.
Selected sections were counterstained with 0.1% thionin.
The sections were examined using both darkfield illumination and Nomarski optics.
Line drawings of sections were made using a projection microscope and the labelled fibers were drawn onto the figures using a camera lucida drawing tube and darkfield illumination.
In addition to the PHA-L material, we examined axonal transport in 17 cases in which injections of WGA-HRP were placed into the ILC (see method below).
In these experiments, the axonal labelling pattern was essentially identical to that seen in the PHA-L series.
However, the PHA-L material allowed detailed observations of axonal morphology and terminations.
We mainly refer to our PHA-L data in this report, with one exception.
Following PHA-L injections into the ILC, we could follow axons into the corticospinal tract, as far as the first few cervical segments, but not to their terminations.
As the WGA-HRP experiments demonstrated the remaining course of spinal axonal labeling, we have relied on these experiments to examine the spinal projection of the ILC.
Retrograde transport experiments
Between 3 and 10 nl of 1% WGA-HRP in phosphate buffer were injected from a glass micropipette into ILC terminal fields using an air pressure injection system (n = 71).

After 48 hours, the animals were deeply anesthetized and perfused transcardially with 0.9% saline followed by 500 ml 1% paraformaldehyde-1.25% glutaraldehyde in 0.1 M phosphate buffer at pH 7.4 and then 250 ml of 10% sucrose in 0.1 M phosphate buffer.
The brains were cut as described above and processed to visualize the WGA-HRP according to the method of de Olmos ( 78).

Following completion of the reaction, the sections were rinsed with cold PBS, mounted onto gelatin-coated slides, counterstained in cold 0.1% thionin, rapidly differentiated in a graded series of cold alcohols, and coverslipped.
Line drawing of the sections were made using a projection microscope, and WGA-HRP filled cells were plotted using a camera lucida drawing tube, under polarized light.

Results.S: RESULTS
Cytoarchitectonic considerations
the ilc , or brodmann area 25 , was designated area iraa by rose ( 27 ) .
The name infralimbic cortex was latter applied to an homologous area by Rose and Woosley ( 48) in the rabbit.

in this report we have followed the terminology of krettek and price ( 77b ) , who described the ilc in the rat as a poorly laminated region in which many neurons from layer i1 extend into the marginal layer , creating an uneven border between these cortical laminae .
The ILC is bounded rostrally by the medial orbital cortex, dorsally by the prelimbic cortex, and posteroventrally by the tenia tecta.
the prelimbic cortex has a well - defined laminar pattern with a homogeneous layer v characterized by fairly large , darkly staining neurons and a bilaminar layer vi .

we have further differentiated the dorsal peduncular cortex as an unlaminated region just ventral to the rostral ilc that is marked by a slight broadening of layer i as compared to the rest of the medial prefrontal cortex ( see paxinos and watson , 86 ) .
in rostral sections , the dorsal peduncular cortex forms a wedge of neurons just dorsomedial to the anterior olfactory nucleus .
as the olfactory bulb separates from the frontal pole , these cells migrate medially and dorsally and are located immediately ventral to the infralimbic cortex and dorsal to the tenia tecta .
Our connectional data, described below, support these cytoarchitectural distinctions (see Fig. 1A).
Anterograde transport experiments
Injection sites.

injections of pha - l were centered in the ilc in 9 cases ( r387 , r457 , r458 , r537 , r642 , r651 , r652 , r674 , r678 ) , the prelimbic cortex in 5 cases ( r375 , r767 , r855 , r858 , r859 ) , and the dorsal peduncular cortex in 3 cases ( r674 , r812 , r862 , see fig . 2a - f ) .
the pattern of efferent projections was similar in each case in which the injection was centered in the ilc .
in experiment r651 , a rather large injection into the ilc at the opening of the forceps minor resulted in labeling of all of the projections seen in other cases .
the majority of pha - l - filled neurons were clustered in layer v with a few present in layers 11 , 111 , and vi .

the injection site extended throughout the rostralcaudal extent of the ilc , including some of the adjacent prelimbic cortex , and at the most rostral pole a few neurons of the medial orbital cortex .
in addition , the injection extended ventrally to include the dorsal peduncular cortex ( fig . 1b ) .

We describe the projections of the ILC primarily with respect to the observations in experiment R651 using the smaller ILC injections and those placed into adjacent cortical areas (Fig. lC,D) to distinguish the efferents from the ILC from those of neighboring cortical regions.
Fiber pathways.
In experiment R651, three major efferent pathways were labelled.
The dorsal pathway was bilaminar.
a small portion of this projection originated from layers 111 , v , and vi and ran dorsally within layer i .
a larger number of fibers originated from layer v and remained in this layer as they ran dorsally through the prelimbic and anterior cingulate areas .
Farther caudally, fibers from the dorsal pathway crossed into the contralateral hemisphere within the ventral-most portion of the genu of the corpus callosum.
other fibers entered the dorsal fornix and from there innervated the dorsal subiculum .
the lateral pathway coursed through the dorsomedial quadrant of the nucleus accumbens , forming tight fascicles of labelled fibers .
at the level of the decussation of the anterior commissure , this cluster of fascicles ran through the ventromedial portion of the striatum immediately adjacent to the lateral ventricle .

slightly caudally at the level of the foramen of monro , individual fascicles fused and formed the ventromedial part of the internal capsule , a position that they maintained throughout the length of the cerebral peduncle and the pyramidal tract .

a smaller number of fibers that followed the lateral pathway did not enter the internal capsule but continued their lateral trajectory through the nucleus accumbens to innervate the dorsal piriform cortex and dorsal agranular insular cortex .
The ventral pathway was by far the largest projection.
it passed through the septo - olfactory area into the deep part of the olfactory tubercle where the labelled fibers encircled but did not enter the islands of calleja .
some labelled fibers continued laterally to innervate the molecular layer of the piriform cortex .
more caudally , most of the labelled fibers ran into the lateral component of the medial forebrain bundle .

at posterior hypothalamic levels , these fibers coursed along the medial edge of the cerebral peduncle , just medial and parallel to the labelled fibers descending via the lateral pathway in the internal capsule .
at the level of the anterior commissure , some of the fibers within the medial forebrain bundle turned dorsally and innervated the lateral septum and the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis .
a few fibers continued through the bed nucleus into the stria terminalis .
others took a dorsomedial turn , hooked around the caudal face of the anterior commissure , and contributed to the innervation of the midline thalamic nuclei .

fibers peeled off from the medial forebrain bundle medially into the adjacent medial preoptic area and hypothalamus and many ran laterally through the ansa peduncularis to provide dense innervation of the amygdala .
in the posterior hypothalamus , as the third ventricle rose to meet the cerebral aqueduct , the fibers within the medial forebrain bundle followed one of three paths .
Some took a dorsomedial trajectory into the periaquedudal gray matter.
others coursed dorsolaterally along the surface of the substantia nigra pars compacta into the central tegmental fields .
In addition, some fibers continued caudally in a ventromedial position.
these fibers contributed to the supramamillary commissure and to innervation of the tuberomamillary nucleus and the interpeduncular nucleus .

at the level of the oculomotor nucleus some ventromedial pathway fibers ran dorsally along the midline into the periaqueductal gray matter , whereas labelled axons from the periaqueductal gray matter swept laterally in the radiation fibers of weisschedel into the central tegmental fields .

in the caudal brainstem , fibers descended through the pyramidal tract and the lateral tegmentum into the medulla , innervating the rostral ventrolateral medulla , nucleus ambiguus , and spinal trigeminal nucleus .

at the level of the facial nucleus , fibers turned dorsally , running medial to the spinal trigeminal nucleus to innervate the ventrolateral , medial and commissural subdivisions of the nucleus of the solitary tract and portions of the dorsal motor vagal nucleus .
in addition to the descending tegmental pathways , labelled fibers could be traced through the corticospinal tract into the first few cervical segments of the spinal cord .
however , no terminal labeling was seen in the spinal cord in the pha - l experiments .

in contrast , when wga - hrp was injected into the ilc , labelled fibers were traced through the corticospinal tract and lateral funiculus to regions of terminal ramification in the dorsal and intermediate gray matter of the spinal cord .
terminal fields telencephalon .

a major advantage of the pha - l technique is that it allows the visualization of preterminal arborizations and varicosities which permits terminal fields and innervation en passage to be distinguished from smooth fibers of passage .
the dorsal efferent pathway from the ilc innervated mainly layers i , v , and vi of the prelimbic and anterior cingulate cortices ( fig . 3a ) .
finely arborized axons and boutons were found throughout these regions .

in addition , labelled fibers and boutons were observed within layers i , 111 , and v of the more caudal portions of the anterior cingulate area , extending to the level at which the anterior commissure crosses the midline .
the piriform cortex received innervation via both the lateral and ventral pathways ( see fig . 3a - d ) .
labelled fibers were observed throughout the rostral piriform cortex , primarily in the molecular and polymorph layers .
fibers in the molecular layer demonstrated varicosities along their lengths , whereas labelled fibers in the polymorph layers only occasionally exhibited swellings .
at rostral levels , the dorsolateral portion of the piriform cortex demonstrated a slightly heavier innervation as compared to other parts of the piriform cortex .
These fibers apparently arose from the lateral efferent pathway.
by the level of the septum and proceeding further caudally , the density of innervation in the piriform cortex began to shift ventrally and arose primarily from the ventral efferent pathway .
the majority of labelled fibers formed a dense plexus within the molecular layer .
some labelled fibers pierced the pyramidal layer perpendicular to the pial surface and entered the polymorph cell layer .
labelled fibers also took a radial course through the nucleus of the lateral olfactory tract .

deep to the piriform cortex , the endopiriform nucleus contained a number of short , fine labelled fibers that had few varicosities along their lengths and ran perpendicular to the external capsule ( fig . 3a ) .
the density of labelled fibers in the agranular insular cortex was most pronounced in layer i ( fig . 3a , b ) .
most pha - l containing fibers within this region were largely short , demonstrated boutons along their lengths and were radially oriented .
labelled fibers in layer i tended to be of a thicker caliber than the smaller numbers of scattered fibers present in the deeper layers of the insular cortex .

throughout the rostrocaudal extent of the amygdaloid complex , labelled fibers of medium or fine caliber with varicosities along their lengths formed a dense plexus of fibers oriented in a medial - to - lateral direction ( fig . 3d - h ) .
these fibers were crossed in turn by other smooth fibers that ran radially toward the pial surface from the anterior and posterior cortical nuclei as well as the periamygdaloid cortex .
the medial subdivision of the central nucleus was particularly heavily innervated by thin and medium caliber fibers demonstrating numerous varicosities ( fig . 4a ) .
the lateral subdivision of the central nucleus contained fewer labelled fibers with only occasional varicosities .
in addition , the central nucleus was encapsulated by relatively smooth labelled axons .
the basolateral and lateral nuclei of the amygdala contained fewer labelled fibers than the adjacent cortical and medial nuclei ( fig . 3e , f ) .

merents to the rostral lateral nucleus were oriented in a dorsoventral fashion and primarily distributed in the dorsolateral subdivision of the nucleus , though in more caudal sections the labelled fibers were observed in the ventral parts as well .
the pha - l labelled fibers observed throughout this nucleus consisted of a mixture of both smooth and bouton - bearing fibers , which were of thin to medium caliber .
relatively smooth axons formed a capsule around the anterior basolateral nucleus .
the lateral portion of this capsule consisted of labelled fibers with occasional boutons , which coursed toward the external capsule .
a small number of labelled fibers traversed the interior of the nucleus in a mediolateral fashion .
labelling was comparatively more sparse in the caudal amygdala ( fig . 3g , h ) .
both smooth and varicose labelled fibers were found in the posterior basolateral and the basomedial nuclei .
the posterior cortical nucleus of the amygdala also contained a few labelled medium and fine caliber fibers with boutons along their lengths .
finally , the amygdalo - hippocampal transition area was innervated by medium caliber fibers with frequent boutons .

in contrast , the dorsal and ventral presubiculum were innervated by fibers with comparatively fewer varicosities and the hippocampus proper contained only a few pha - l labelled fibers , mainly in the molecular layer of the ca1 cell field ( fig . 3h ) .
these fibers were of a relatively thin caliber and generally smooth with occasional branches that demonstrated clusters of boutons .
the lateral entorhinal cortex received a projection of medium caliber fibers with boutons which were primarily distributed to the deeper cortical layers .
a few labelled fibers were observed in layers i and 111 .
the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis contained a number of fine to medium caliber fibers that exhibited numerous varicosities along their lengths .
these fibers were clustered primarily in the lateral and ventrolateral subdivisions of this cell group ( figs . 3b , 4b ) .
the nucleus accumbens ( fig . 3a ) exhibited numerous fascicles of labelled fibers that followed a diagonal trajectory across the nucleus from dorsomedial to ventrolateral .
fine and medium caliber individual labelled fibers branched profusely , exhibiting numerous boutons along their lengths .
in the ventral putamen ( fig . 3a ) , smooth labelled fibers clustered together to form several fascicles .
in addition to these bundles of labelled axons , a dense plexus of labelled fibers was also present throughout the ventral putamen .
these fibers were of medium or fine caliber , were oriented in a medial to lateral direction , and exhibited numerous branch points and boutons along their lengths .
the innervation of the contralateral telencephalon was similar to that described for the ipsilateral hemisphere though it was considerably more sparse .
one exception was the contralateral entorhinal cortex , which did not contain any labelled fibers .
Thalamus.

the midline thalamic nuclei contained labelled fibers that appeared to arise from the dorsal component of the ventral efferent pathway that ran along the wall of the third ventricle caudal to the anterior commissure .

in the most rostra1 portion of the thalamus , medium and fine labelled fibers with densely clustered varicosities were found predominantly in the dorsomedial part of the ipsilateral paratenial nucleus where they were oriented in a dorsoventral direction ( fig . 3c ) .
a smaller number of finer fibers with boutons along their lengths , also oriented in a dorsoventral direction , were present in the paraventricular nucleus of the thalamus ( fig . 3d - f ) .
a dense terminal arborization was present along the lateral border of the paraventricular nucleus of the thalamus throughout its rostrocaudal extent .
labeled fibers tended to cluster along the medial edge of the mediodorsal nucleus where they were oriented in a dorsoventral direction ( fig . 5a ) .
thin labelled fibers with boutons along their lengths were concentrated within the ventral half of the ventromedial nucleus .
in the reuniens nucleus , ( fig . 3d ) labelled fibers of medium and fine caliber exhibited numerous swellings and boutons along their lengths .

these axons were oriented in a mediolateral direction , though along the midline of the nucleus there were several fibers that coursed in a dorsoventral direction , apparently ascending as part of the dorsal component of the ventral pathway toward the paraventricular and paratenial thalamic nuclei .

in more caudal sections the innervation of the reuniens nucleus became so dense that the orientation of individual fibers was obscured , though the terminal - like processes seemed largely to be located in the ventral half of the nucleus ( see fig . 3c - f ) .
in experiment r651 , the submedial nucleus also contained a small but dense plexus of medium caliber labelled fibers with varicosities ( fig . 3e ) .

this terminal field was not seen in experiments r652 or r678 in which the injection was confined to the ilc and ventral prelimbic cortex but was present in experiments r674 , r812 , and r682 , which included the dorsal peduncular cortex .
Hence the submedial terminal projection was probably due to the inclusion of the dorsal peduncular cortex in the injection site in experiment R651.
in more caudal sections through the thalamus , labelled efferents were seen within the parafasicular and subparafasicular nuclei ( fig . 3g ) .
these fibers were of a relatively thin caliber with few swellings or varicosities .
a few smooth , labelled fibers with occasional varicosities also ran laterally into the ventroposterior medial parvocellular and lateral subparafasicular nuclei .
labelled fibers crossed the midline thalamus at two points : in the reuniens nucleus and immediately ventral to the paraventricular nucleus of the thalamus .
although fewer pha - l labelled fibers were observed in the contralateral thalamus in experiment r651 , these were distributed in an identical pattern to the ipsilateral hemisphere .
Hypothalamus.
the innervation of the hypothalamus in experiment r651 was mainly derived from the ventral pathway .
its principal target was the lateral hypothalamic area , in particular its ventrolateral and perifornical regions ( figs . 3d - g , 5c , d ) .
although innervation of the anterior part of the lateral hypothalamic area was scant , varicose fibers running in a mediolateral direction were prominent in the retrochiasmatic area .
some fibers , running parallel to the optic tract , continued laterally into the ansa peduncularis .
there was a gradual increase from rostral to caudal in the density of labelled fibers in the ventrolateral hypothalamus .
at tuberal and posterior levels , a dense plexus of medium to fine caliber varicose fibers was seen along the medial margin of the internal capsule and extended to the ventral surface of the brain .
perifornical labelled fibers were also more numerous caudally , forming a dense cluster dorsolateral to the fornix .
at the premamillary level , fibers in the perifornical area either swept medially into the central grey matter or ventrally into the ventrolateral group .
the latter became confluent with a dense terminal field in the tuberomamillary nucleus .
in general there was only sparse innervation of medial hypothalamic structures in experiment r651 .
at the rostral tip of the third ventricle labelled fibers oriented in a dorsoventral direction were seen within the anteroventral periventricular nucleus ( fig . 3b ) .
the fibers were of either medium or fine caliber with varicosities and stalks distributed along their lengths .
some terminals also appeared as punctate labelling covering neuronal cell bodies .

within the medial preoptic area labelled fibers , organized in a mediolateral orientation , were generally of a medium diameter with boutons and stalk - like appendages distributed along their lengths ( fig . 3b ) .
These fibers gave off branches that were thinner than the parent fiber and tended to be smooth.
In addition, many well-filled fibers of a larger caliber crossed the preoptic region on a diagonal, arcing in a ventromedial to dorsolateral direction.
labelled fibers were more numerous in the dorsal half of the suprachiasmatic nucleus than in the ventral half ( figs . 3c , 6 also swanson et al . , ' 87 ) .
fibers in the dorsal half of the nucleus were either of fine caliber and smooth with an occasional varicosity , or were of a medium caliber , exhibiting numerous varicosities along their lengths .
labelled fibers in the ventral half of the suprachiasmatic nucleus were generally smooth , exhibiting only a few bouton - like structures .
labelled fibers coursed along the dorsolateral border of the supraoptic nucleus ( fig . 3c , d ) .
a few medium caliber fibers with occasional varicosities entered the nucleus and distributed themselves amongst the most peripherally located magnocellular neurons .
These regions of termination were concentrated in the more lateral aspects of the nucleus.
in addition , a few smooth labelled fibers were seen within the ipsilateral optic tract .
these labelled fibers then ran directly into the supraoptic nucleus where they branched and demonstrated varicosities along their lengths .
these fibers did not proceed very far into the nucleus , but appeared to maintain a close association with the optic tract .

like the supraoptic nucleus , the paraventricular nucleus of the hypothalamus was also surrounded by a plexus of medium caliber fibers with terminal processes that closely followed the contours of its borders ( fig . 3d ) .
a few thin , labelled fibers that exhibited occasional boutons and varicosities along their lengths were also observed coursing through the parvocellular portion of the paraventricular nucleus .

within the dorsal hypothalamic area ( just dorsal to the dorsomedial nucleus in fig . 3f ) , there were fibers of both fine and medium caliber that exhibited multiple branches with numerous boutons , varicosities , and stalk - like appendages as they followed the dorsal contour of the paraventricular nucleus .
in addition a number of labelled fibers appeared to cross the midline just above the third ventricle .
in the zona incerta labelled fibers followed the mediolateral orientation of the nucleus and tended to be rather long , of medium caliber , and smooth , with only an occasional swelling .
the branches that came off of these labelled fibers were generally of a finer caliber and exhibited a denser distribution of boutons and stalk - like appendages .
most of the labelled fibers were concentrated in the medial aspects of this region , just dorsal to the paraventricular nucleus of the hypothalamus ( fig . 3d , e ) .

many pha - l labelled fibers within the periuerztricular nucleus of the hypothalamus were oriented in a dorsoventral direction , running parallel to the surface of the third ventricle ( fig . 3c - e ) .

some wrapped around the ventral aspect of the ventricle , maintaining their orientation parallel to its surface ( fig . 3d ) , whereas others entered the arcuate nucleus and maintained their general dorsoventral orientation .
many of the labelled fibers within the periventricular nucleus sent branches bearing boutons among the ependymal cells lining the third ventricle .
labelled fibers located in the dorsal half of the periventricular nucleus were of a medium caliber , had a wavy appearance , and also demonstrated many boutons along their lengths .
a few of the labelled fibers in the periventricular nucleus were long , straight processes that were devoid of varicosities .
within the rostral dorsomedial nucleus , medium and fine caliber fibers filled with pha - l swept in a mediolateral direction across the dorsal half of the nucleus ( see fig . 3f ) .
These fibers tended to branch, giving off collaterals at right angles that exhibited numerous boutons and stalks along their lengths.

in more caudal sections , most of the labelled fibers within the dorsomedial nucleus avoided the compact zone , although a small number of fine caliber , smooth fibers were present along the lateral border of the subnucleus .
labeled efferents to the ventromedial nucleus of the hypothalamus were limited to a small number of fibers along the dorsal border of the cell group ( fig . 3e ) .
most were short , devoid of varicosities and ran in the cell - poor capsular region that encircled the ventromedial nucleus .
a few labelled fibers , passing through the capsule perpendicular to its surface , had varicosities along their lengths .

as the caudal third ventricle ascended to join the cerebral aqueduct , medium and thin caliber labelled fibers in the posterior hypothalamic area formed a crisscrossing network of axons bearing terminal processes ( fig . 3g ) .

in experiment r651 in which the injection of pha - l included part of the dorsal peduncular cortex and a few cells deep to the tenia tecta in addition to the ilc , numerous medium and fine caliber labelled fibers with terminal processes were found throughout the supramamillary nucleus .
an extremely dense band of labelled fibers and terminals was observed along the dorsal aspect of the medial mammillary nucleus and filled its median portion ( fig . 3h ) .

in experiment r652 in which the dorsal peduncular cortex and tenia tecta were excluded from the injection site , only the supramamillary nucleus contained labelled fibers , indicating that the ilc projects primarily to this area .
in experiment r674 , the injection site included a few neurons in the ventral ilc but principally involved the dorsal peduncular cortex .
in this case , only the dense band of labelled fibers along the dorsal border of the medial mamillary nucleus demonstrated pha - l labelled fibers .
These data indicate that the projection from the medial frontal cortex to the mamillary body is topographically organized.

the infralimbic cortex projects to the supramamillary nucleus while the more ventrally located dorsal peduncular cortex projects to the region of the mamillary body immediately ventral to the ilc terminal field .
the tenia tecta also appears to project to the wedge - shaped median part of the medial mamillary nucleus ( see discussion ) .
labeled innervation of the contralateral hypothalamus followed a pattern similar to the ipsilateral side although less dense .
notable differences were the contralateral paraventricular and supraoptic nuclei , neither of which appeared to receive any innervation in experiment r651 .
Mesencephalon.
labelled fibers in the medial forebrain bundle swept dorsomedially through the posterior hypothalamic area into the ventrolateral quadrant of the periaqueductal gray matter ( fig . 31 ) .
some of these fibers ran through the edinger - westphal nucleus into the periaqueductal gray matter and dorsal raphe nucleus .

within the periaqueductal gray matter the densest collection of labelled fibers was located near the aqueduct , including fine , smooth fibers as well as medium caliber fibers bearing numerous boutons ( see fig . 7a , see also fig . 3h - k ) .
farther laterally , the density of labelled fibers dropped off and those fibers present tended to be smooth .
a few thin , wavy , bouton - bearing fibers ran in the periaqueductal gray matter dorsal to the aqueduct near the midline .
pha - l containing fibers were also found amongst the ependymal cells of the aqueduct , as along the third ventricle .
labelled radiation fibers of weisschedel took a ventrolateral trajectory through the central tegmental fields .
these were of a fine caliber and devoid of terminal varicosities .

other labelled fibers originating in the medial forebrain bundle traveled in the dorsolateral tegmental pathway , coursing laterally over the dorsal surface of the substantia nigra pars compacta ( fig . 31 ) .
some of these fibers innervated the peripeduncular nucleus , providing a sparse distribution of terminals .
other fibers continued dorsomedially and joined the radiation fibers of weisschedel to innervate the central tegmental fields .
labelled fibers which traveled in the ventromedial tegmental pathway innervated the interpeduncular nucleus .
these fibers were primarily located in the dorsal part of the nucleus and while generally smooth did exhibit occasional terminal boutons ( fig . 35 ) .
Pons.

terminal labelling within the parabrachial nucleus arose as a caudal and lateral extension of the fibers coursing through the periaqueductal gray matter and central tegmental fields ( see fig . 7b see also fig . 3l , m ) .
in the rostral parabrachial nucleus , a few labelled fibers of fine caliber found in the superior lateral subnucleus exhibited infrequent swellings along their lengths .

within the central lateral subnucleus there was a denser collection of spinelike processes and boutons along the lengths of fine caliber fibers as they coursed laterally from the periaqueductal gray matter .
both medium and fine caliber fibers , observed within the dorsal and external lateral subnuclei , exhibited boutons and varicosities along their lengths .
in the ventrolateral parabrachial subnucleus fine caliber fibers were observed , which also demonstrated varicosities along their lengths .
in caudal sections through the parabrachial nucleus , labeling within these subnuclei grew denser .
labeled fibers within the medial subnucleus were oriented in a mediolateral direction .
These tended to be smooth with occasional swellings along their lengths in the more lateral part of the subnucleus.
in the more medial part of the nucleus , these labelled fibers branched and gave rise to finer axons with complex bouton - bearing processes .
labelled fibers within the dorsal lateral subnucleus were oriented in a direction parallel to the contours of the superior cerebellar peduncle .

in the adjacent external lateral subnucleus , the ilc efferent fibers rostrally were smooth and oriented perpendicular to the superior cerebellar peduncle , but in more caudal sections these fibers shifted so that they too ran parallel to the surface of the superior cerebellar peduncle and then demonstrated varicosities .
some pha - l labelled fibers also wrapped around the lateral tail of the peduncle rostrally , within the extreme lateral subnucleus .
in addition , a few labelled fibers pierced the superior cerebellar peduncle and ran through it in a dorsoventral direction .
other structures in the pontine tegmentum that demonstrated pha - l containing fibers included the mesencephalic trigeminal nucleus and the locus coeruleus ( see fig . 3m ) .
only a few medium - size fibers were seen coursing among the large neurons of the mesencephalic trigeminal nucleus , but an occasional varicosity was seen in close proximity to a cell body .
smooth labelled fibers with occasional boutons were present in the dorsal , rostral portion of the locus coeruleus .
medial to the locus coeruleus , the central gray matter also contained a number of smooth , fine caliber labelled fibers as did the dorsal and pontine raphe nuclei .

within the base of the pons , the medial pontine nuclei were innervated bilaterally along their most medial border by a small but very dense cluster of large and medium caliber labelled fibers with numerous boutons .
these fibers appeared to originate from those descending in the medial part of the cerebral peduncle .
Medulla.
fine labelled fibers in the ventrolateral and ventromedial tegmental pathways contributed to sparse innervation of the ventrolateral medulla ( see fig . 3p , q ) .
some of these were straight fibers and devoid of varicosities others followed a more tortuous path and exhibited varicosities along their lengths .

in more caudal sections , labelled fibers in the area ventral to the compact formation of the nucleus ambiguus were of both medium and fine caliber and all appeared to have varicosities along their lengths .
the compact zone of the nucleus ambiguus received a small number of short , fine labelled axons that exhibited swellings and boutons .
this innervation appeared to become denser more caudally and extended into the external formation of the nucleus .

labelled fibers ran dorsally in a position medial to the spinal trigeminal nucleus and innervated the ventrolateral , medial and commissural subdivisions of the nucleus of the solitary tract as well as the dorsal motor vagal nucleus ( see figs . 30 - r , 7c , d ) .
in sections through the rostral nucleus of the solitary tract there were numerous medium and fine wavy fibers with many varicosities along their lengths .

labeled fibers were not seen in the rostral nucleus of the solitary tract in experiment r678 in which the injection site was confined to the ilc , indicating that this projection may originate from the prelimbic cortex ( see below ) .

in experiment r651 , the pattern of fibers seen in the medial subdivision of the nucleus of the solitary tract was similar to the rostral subdivision , with the addition that finelabelled fibers with boutons and swellings swept into the layer of ependymal cells lining the fourth ventricle ( fig . 7d ) .
the ventrolateral portion of the nucleus of the solitary tract was innervated by fibers that appeared to be a continuation of the thick , straight axons of the lateral tegmental pathway .
these axons branched profusely giving rise to numerous medium and fine caliber fibers bearing boutons and varicosities along their lengths .
the commissural portion of the nucleus of the solitary tract was innervated by a few fine - labelled fibers that had stalk - like processes and boutons along their lengths .

finally , the dorsal motor vagal nucleus was also innervated by fine caliber fibers that ran along its dorsal surface and gave rise to numerous fine branches which entered the nucleus and exhibited varicosities .
spinal cord .
as stated previously , due to technical limitations we could not trace descending fibers in the pyramidal tract to their termination in pha - l material .

however , following injections of wga - hrp into the ilc ( r385 , r386 , r389 , r398 , r400 , r441 , and r442 ) , labelled fibers within the pyramidal tract could be traced through the pyramidal decussation into the base of the contralateral dorsal column where they descended as part of the corticospinal tract .

labeled fibers were also observed in a direct continuation of the lateral tegmental pathway that descended bilaterally , although with an ipsilateral predominance , in the dorsolateral funiculus through the entire length of the spinal cord ( fig . 8a ) .
wga - hrp filled fibers could be followed longitudinally through the dorsal commissural nucleus .

in transverse sections through the spinal cord labelled fibers could be followed laterally from the dorsal commissural nucleus and could be observed among the sympathetic preganglionic neurons of the intermediolatera1 cell column ( fig . 8b ) .
there were also wga - hrp labelled fibers running in a longitudinal direction throughout lamina i at all segments of the spinal dorsal horn .
control pha - l injections
case r651 was chosen for illustration because it demonstrated all of the features of the efferent projections labelled by our series of injections into the ilc .
however , neurons of the ventral prelimbic cortex , the dorsal peduncular cortex , and tenia tecta were also included in this injection site .
in order to confirm the specificity of ilc efferent projections , we undertook a number of control experiments in which pha - l was iontophoresed into the cortical fields adjacent to the ilc .
in one series of control experiments ( r674 , r812 , and r862 see fig . 2 ) , the injections were centered within the dorsal peduncular cortex .
in sections through the frontal pole an occasional labelled fiber was observed in layer i1 or i11 of either the ilc or the prelimbic cortex .
these fibers were of a fine caliber and exhibited varicosities along their lengths .

in more caudal sections , numerous very fine caliber labelled fibers with profuse branching and many varicosities were observed within layer i at the junction between the prelimbic and anterior cingulate cortices .
additional cortical innervation was observed within layer i of the ventral agranular insular cortex and consisted of a small population of fine caliber fibers with varicosities .
fine and medium caliber fibers with boutons formed a discrete terminal field ventromedial to the basolateral nucleus of the amygdala .
these fibers ran along the capsule that surrounds the basolateral nucleus and primarily appeared to be innervating the intercalated nucleus that is present at this level .
a few labelled fibers also extended into the lateral subdivision of the central nucleus .
hence the dorsal peduncular cortex may have made a minor contribution to some of the cortical and amygdaloid projections seen in r651 .

by contrast , the submedial nucleus of the thalamus demonstrated a dense plexus of labelled fibers bearing numerous varicosities , indicating that the innervation of this nucleus in experiment r651 probably could be attributed to inclusion of the dorsal peduncular cortex in the injection site .

this hypothesis was confirmed by experiments r652 and r678 , in which an injection of pha - l limited to the ilc and excluding the dorsal peduncular cortex failed to label fibers within the submedial nucleus of the thalamus .

in addition , injections of pha - l into the dorsal peduncular cortex resulted in the labelling of a band - like region along the dorsal aspect of the medial mamillary nucleus immediately ventral to the supramamillary nucleus .

a similar terminal pattern was seen in experiment r651 in which the injection site included the dorsal peduncular cortex , but not after the ilc injections in experiments r652 and r678 , which excluded the dorsal peduncular cortex .
only the most rostral dorsal peduncular cortex injection , r812 , labelled fibers to the lateral hypothalamic area , and no more caudal projections were observed .
therefore , in experiment r651 labelling in the lateral hypothalamic area and brainstem cannot be attributed to the dorsal peduncular cortex .
in an additional series of control experiments , injections of pha - l were centered in the prelimbic cortex ( r767 , r852 , r855 , r858 , r859 ) .
in experiment r767 , the injection was confined to the prelimbic cortex , labelling all of the efferent projections that were seen in the prelimbic cortex series .
In general, our results were similar to those reported by Sesack et al. ('89).

within the telencephalon , the prelimbic cortex had extensive projections to all of the cortical areas located along the medial surface of the frontal lobe including layers i , 11 , 111 , and v of the medial orbital cortex , the tenia tecta , the dorsal peduncular cortex , the ilc , and the anterior cingulate cortex .
in addition , the prelimbic cortex was found to innervate the anterior olfactory nucleus , the claustrum , and the agranular insular cortex .
All of these projections were bilateral with an ipsilateral predominance.
in contrast , in experiment r678 in which the injection site involved the ilc but not the prelimbic cortex , the cortical labeling was similar in pattern but sparser than in experiment r651 .
hence both the ilc and the prelimbic cortex probably contributed to the pattern of cortical labelling seen in experiment r65 1 .

in experiment r767 , labelled fibers bearing varicosities were observed within the lateral subdivision of the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis , although to a lesser extent than was observed following an injection into the infralimbic cortex .
the amygdala received virtually no labelled fibers from the rostral prelimbic cortex with the exception of a single labelled fiber observed within the medial nucleus .
in experiment r855 , the injection of pha - l was placed more caudally in the prelimbic cortex and a cluster of labelled fibers was observed within the ipsilateral posterior basolateral nucleus .
within the thalamus , the prelimbic cortex innervated the paratenial nucleus as well as the border zone located between the paraventricular and mediodorsal nuclei .
the densest portion of labelling within the border zone was dorsolateral to that seen following injections of the infralimbic cortex .
in addition , the medial portion of the mediodorsal nucleus itself was innervated by the prelimbic cortex ( see fig . 4b ) .

the ventral portion of the reuniens nucleus of the thalamus received afferents from the prelimbic cortex in case r767 however , the density of this innervation was much less than that observed following ilc injections .
Innervation of the hypothalamus by the prelimbic cortex was relatively scant in experiment R767.
a few labelled fibers were observed within the anteroventral periventricular and medial preoptic nuclei .
in addition , a small number of labelled axons coursed around the paraventricular nucleus in a pattern similar to that described above for experiment r651 .

a few other labelled axons were observed that ran parallel to the ventricular wall within the periventricular nucleus , and still other fibers were observed that coursed though the retrochiasmatic region of the lateral hypothalamus in a mediolateral direction .
a single labelled axon was observed that followed the contours of the supraoptic nucleus but did not innervate it .
the zona incerta also exhibited a small number of labelled fibers .
more posteriorly , the supramamillary nucleus contained only a few labelled fibers in case r767 .
labelled fibers were also observed in the tuberomamillary nucleus .

in agreement with earlier reports , fibers from the prelimbic cortex were seen in the dorsolateral quadrant of the periaqueductal gray matter ( hardy and leichnetz , ' 81 wyss and sripanidulchai , ' 84 ) as well as in the nucleus of the solitary tract .
we also observed a few labelled fibers in the compact zone of the nucleus ambiguus .

following injections of wga - hrp into the prelimbic cortex ( r906 , r907 , r913 , r914 , r915 ) , labelled axons could be traced through the cervical and thoracic segments of the spinal cord within lamina i of the dorsal horn , the lateral funiculus , and the ventral portion of the dorsal funiculus .
in addition , several labelled fibers could be followed into laminae x , but none were observed within the intermediolateral cell column .
the above findings indicate a degree of overlap in the efferent projections of the prelimbic and infralimbic cortices .
however , with few exceptions the descending projections from the ilc to each of these sites are more extensive and denser than those from the prelimbic cortex .
Retrograde experiments
although our injections of pha - l were rather small , it was not possible to exclude completely adjacent areas , nor did we fill every cell within the ilc with the lectin .
in addition , as indicated above , the ilc may share certain projections with the adjacent areas , making distinctions difficult in anterograde tracer experiments .
we therefore placed injections of wga - hrp into the terminals fields of the ilc in order to determine more precisely the cells of origin of projections from the medial prefrontal cortex .
telencephalon .

an injection of wga - hrp was made into the anterior cingulate cortex in experiment r38 , which resulted in the retrograde labelling of neurons in layer i11 and the superficial portion of layer v of the ilc .

injections of wga - hrp made into the prelimbic cortex ( r720 and r721 ) retrogradely labelled neurons in the ilc , which formed a band in layer 11 , were loosely scattered throughout layer 111 , and formed another band in the deep portion of layer v .
these experiments confirm the observation that the dorsal efferent pathway , which exits from the ilc innervates both the prelimbic cortex and the anterior cingulate cortex .
an injection of wga - hrp was confined to the anterior portion of the piriform cortex in experiment r89 .

whereas this resulted in a number of labelled fibers in layers i and i11 of the ilc , the only retrogradely labelled neurons observed were in the dorsal peduncular cortex and the deeper layers of the tenia tecta , thus confirming that the majority of labelled fibers in the piriform cortex arose from the dorsal peduncular cortex .

injections into the endopiriform nucleus ( r560 ) failed to retrogradely label neurons in the medial prefrontal cortex , suggesting that the pha - l labelled fibers observed in this nucleus were fibers of passage , in keeping with the observation that these fibers were devoid of varicosities .

injections placed into the posteroventral insular cortex ( r31 ) or that were large enough to include all of the insular cortex ( r36 ) resulted in the retrograde labelling of a small number of neurons in layer 111 of the more posterior portion of the ilc .

injections placed in the more anterior parts of the insular cortex ( r19 , r34 , r35 , r86 , r87 ) resulted in a number of labelled fibers throughout the layers of the ilc , but retrogradely labelled neurons were found only in the rostral prelimbic cortex , just dorsal to the ilc .
injections of wga - hrp were made into the amygdala in 11 rats .
in experiment r556 the injection was centered in the medial division of the central nucleus ( see fig . 9 ) .
the labeling observed in the ilc following this injection was the most extensive in this series of experiments .
retrogradely labelled neurons were present in layer i11 of the ipsilateral rostral ilc and extended into the dorsal peduncular cortex .
there were comparatively more labelled neurons in the posterior ilc and these also occupied layer i11 of the ventral half of the ilc and the dorsal part of the dorsal peduncular cortex ( fig . 10 ) .
in experiments r403 and r671 , the injections were centered in the lateral division of the central nucleus , which receives a rather sparse afferent input from the ilc .
in both cases there were a few retrogradely labelled neurons observed within layers i11 and v of the ventral half of the ipsilateral ilc .
in addition , a few labelled cells were found ventrally in the dorsal peduncular cortex and occupying the deeper layers of the tenia tecta .
no contralateral labelling was observed in these cases .

in experiment r567 , an injection into the ventromedial portion of the anterior amygdaloid area resulted in retrogradely labelled neurons in layers i11 andv of the ipsilateral ilc throughout its rostrocaudal extent .
these neurons were or the most part located in the ventral half of the ilc , extending through the dorsal peduncular cortex , and a few were observed in the layers deep to the tenia tecta .
there was no labelling in the contralateral hemisphere in this experiment .
in experiment r313 , an injection was made into the basolateral amygdaloid nucleus .
relatively large retrogradely labelled cells were present in layers i1 and i11 of the dorsal peduncular cortex , the prelimbic cortex , and the ilc .
within the prelimbic cortex , small retrogradely labelled neurons were present in layer 111 , whereas larger labelled pyramidal cells were present in layer 11 .
in caudal sections , the retrogradely labelled neurons were primarily located in layer 111 of the prelimbic cortex and ilc .

in experiment r532 , an injection of wga - hrp was placed ventromedial to the basolateral nucleus , adjacent to the capsule that surrounds this nucleus and centered in the intercalated nucleus present at this level .
sections through the medial prefrontal cortex demonstrated that retrogradely labelled neurons were confined to the dorsal peduncular cortex .
in summary , the cells in both layers i11 and v of the ilc innervate the medial subdivision of the ipsilateral central nucleus of the amygdala and the anterior amygdaloid area .
the basolateral nucleus of the amygdala receives inputs from neurons in layers i1 and 111 of the prelimbic cortex and , to a lesser extent , the ilc .
in contrast , innervation of the intercalated nucleus located medial to the basolateral nucleus is derived exclusively from the dorsal peduncular cortex .

injections of wga - hrp made into the lateral division of the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis ( r528 and r698 ) resulted in a band of retrogradely labelled neurons in the ilc in the superficial part of layer v and , to a lesser extent , in layer 111 , which ran from the ventral prelimbic cortex through the ilc to the dorsal part of the dorsal peduncular cortex ( fig . 9 ) .
at more caudal levels , the labelled cells were primarily located in the dorsal peduncular cortex and layer v of the ilc .
the labelling in all of these cases was confined to the ipsilateral hemisphere .
in experiments where the injection of wga - hrp was placed more medially ( r527 , r564 and r569 ) , fewer retrogradely labelled neurons were apparent in the ilc .
in experiment r735 , an injection of wga - hrp was placed in the medial part of the nucleus accumbens .
this injection spread to include the deepest layers of the tenia tecta and resulted in the retrograde labelling of ilc neurons in layers i11 and v .
Thalamus.
in experiments r478 and r579 , injections of wga - hrp were placed into the mediodorsal nucleus , including the border zone with the paraventricular nucleus of the thalamus .

in both of these cases , an unbroken band of retrogradely labelled neurons was seen in layer vi throughout the medial prefrontal cortex from the dorsal peduncular cortex , through the ilc and prelimbic cortex and into the anterior cingulate cortex ( fig . 10 ) .

more laterally placed injections into the mediodorsal nucleus that avoided the border zone produced a similar pattern of retrograde labeling except that few , if any , labelled neurons were seen in the ilc .

an injection made into the paraventricular nucleus of the thalamus in experiment r297 ( see fig . 11 ) produced only a small number of retrogradely labelled cells in the medial prefrontal cortex , but these were distributed as in the border zone injections .
these experiments emphasize that the border zone between the paraventricular and mediodorsal nuclei is an important terminal field for ilc efferent projections to the thalamus .
in experiment r584 an injection of the tracer wga - hrp was made into the reuniens nucleus .
retrogradely labelled neurons were observed in the dorsal half of the dorsal peduncular cortex and in layer v in the ventral half of the ilc .

in rostral sections retrogradely labelled neurons were primarily located in the claustrum and the wedge portion of the dorsal peduncular cortex with only a few labelled cells present in layer v of the rostral ilc and prelimbic cortex .
a few labelled cells arced over the genu of the corpus callosum and were present dorsally in layer v of the anterior cingulate cortex .
wga - hrp injected into the submedial nucleus of the thalamus in experiment r648 retrogradely filled cells within the rostral part of the dorsal peduncular cortex and the claustrum .
labeled neurons were not seen in the ilc , in results of the anterograde transport agreement with the experiments .
Hypothalamus.
injections of wga - hrp were placed into the lateral hypothalamic area in 6 experiments .
in experiments r121 and r437 the injection was centered in the posterior portion of the lateral hypothalamic area at the premamillary level between the fornix and cerebral peduncle .
retrogradely labelled cells in experiment r121 were clustered rostrally in the dorsal peduncular cortex and in the superficial portion of layer v of the ilc ( fig . 12 ) .

in more caudal sections , these formed a band of labelled cells that extended throughout layer v of both areas , and broadened to include a smaller number of cells in more superficial cortical layers .
retrogradely labelled neurons were also observed within layer v of the agranular insular cortex .
three injections of wga - hrp were made into the tuberal component of the lateral hypothalamus .
in experiment r235 the injection was centered immediately ventromedial to the fornix at the level of the ventromedial nucleus .
this resulted in retrograde labeling of neurons within layers i11 and v of the ilc throughout its rostrocaudal and dorsoventral extent .
a few labelled neurons were also observed within the ventral prelimbic cortex , whereas none were present in either the dorsal peduncular cortex or the insular cortex .

in experiment r466 , the injection of wga - hrp was placed at a similar rostrocaudal level to case r235 but centered dorsolateral to the fornix and midway between this fiber tract and the cerebral peduncle ( fig . 12 ) .
only a few retrogradely labelled cells were observed in the cortex following this injection , mainly in the superficial component of layer v of the ilc and the adjacent dorsal peduncular cortex .
in experiment r530 , the injection of wga - hrp was placed in a location similar to that described for case r466 but closer to the fornix .
this placement resulted in a larger number of similarly distributed retrogradely labelled cells within the ilc .
neither experiment r466 nor r530 resulted in labelled cells within the insular cortex .
in experiment r408 , the anterior lateral hypothalamic area was injected with wga - hrp .
this injection was made at the level of the posterior parvocellular part of the paraventricular nucleus of the hypothalamus , lateral to the fornix and dorsomedial to the optic tract .

labeled cells were present in layer i11 and the superficial component of layer v of the dorsal half of the dorsal peduncular cortex and the ventral part of the ilc throughout its rostrocaudal extent .
an occasional labelled cell was also seen within layer i11 or v of the prelimbic cortex .
in experiment r632 , the injection of tracer was made immediately ventral to the midportion of the paraventricular nucleus into the anterior hypothalamic area .

in this case , the retrograde labeling in layer v of the rostral ilc and prelimbic cortex was similar to that seen in experiment r408 , but fewer labelled cells were present in the dorsal peduncular cortex .
in experiment r563 , the lateral half of the dorsomedial nucleus of the hypothalamus was injected with tracer at the level of the compact subnucleus .
this injection spread ventrally to include the dorsal capsular portion of the ventromedial nucleus of the hypothalamus .
the dorsal half of the ilc contained a few retrogradely labelled neurons in the superficial component of layer v that were continuous with labelled cells in the prelimbic cortex .
a few labelled cells were also present in layer i11 of the ilc .
to summarize , the ilc provides most of the innervation from the medial frontal cortex to each of the hypothalamic terminal fields identified in pha - l experiment r651 .
these projections arise primarily from layer v with a smaller contribution from layer 111 , particularly from the caudal ilc .

the dorsal peduncular cortex also contributes to the projections to the lateral part of the lateral hypothalamic area , whereas the prelimbic and anterior cingulate areas provided additional innervation of certain medial hypothalamic sites .
Mesencephalon.
the periaqueductal gray matter was injected with wga - hrp in two cases .
in case r775 , the injection was centered in the ventrolateral quadrant of this region , but spread dorsally .
this resulted in a greater number of labelled neurons in the prelimbic cortex than in case r535 in which only the ventrolateral periaqueductal gray matter was injected ( see fig . 13 ) .
in both of these experiments a band of retrogradely labelled cells was observed in layer i11 and v through the rostral ilc into the prelimbic cortex .
at mid - rostrocaudal levels , the labelling in the prelimbic cortex dropped out in case r535 and a larger number of retrogradely labelled cells was observed in the ilc .
in caudal sections through the ilc very few labelled cells were present .
pons and medulla .
following injections of wga - hrp into the parabrachial nucleus , a dense cluster of retrogradely labelled neurons was observed within layer v of the ilc .
the number of retrogradely labelled neurons observed in this cortical region was somewhat greater when injections were larger ( r383 , 351 , r407 ) .

in experiment r407 ( fig . 141 , three small injections totalling 20 nl were made into the parabrachial nucleus , essentially filling the lateral and medial subnuclei with tracer ( see herbert et al . , ' 90 , for a detailed description of this injection site ) .
in rostral sections through the ilc a few labelled cells were present in the wedge of dorsal peduncular cortex .
labelled neurons in the ilc formed a band in the deep component of layer v that extended throughout its dorsoventral and rostrocaudal extent ( see fig . 10 ) .
in caudal sections labelled cells were also found in the more superficial cortical layers of the ilc .

a series of smaller injections was placed into the parabrachid nucleus ( herbert et al . , ' 90 ) in an effort to further define the source of ilc innervation to its various subnuclei , but these experiments did not demonstrate any topographical organization within the ilc projection to the parabrachial complex .
in six experiments , injections were placed into the nucleus of the solitary tract .

in experiment r547 , the rostral nucleus of the solitary tract was injected with wga - hrp and resulted in the retrograde filling of neurons within the caudal ilc located close to the border between the ilc and the prelimbic cortex .
in experiment r536 the medial and adjacent rostral commissural subdivisions of nucleus of the solitary tract were included in the injection site as was the dorsal motor vagal nucleus .
the injection site in experiment r518 included the dorsal motor vagal nucleus as well as the medial subdivision of the nucleus of the solitary tract .
the pattern of labelling in these cases was similar , consisting of a bilateral band of retrogradely labelled neurons in layer v of the dorsal ilc and the ventral prelimbic cortex .
fewer retrogradely labelled cells were present in the caudal ilc .

when the injection was placed in the ventrolateral division of the nucleus of the solitary tract , as in experiments r543 , r518 , r493 , and r498 , few , if any , retrogradely labelled neurons were seen in the ilc .
following injections placed in the caudal commissural subdivision , no retrogradely labelled neurons could be found in the ilc .
four injections of wga - hrp were placed into the rostral ventrolateral medulla .

in experiments r199 and r200 the medial portion of the rostral ventrolateral medulla was injected with wga - hrp and in both cases a few neurons in layer v of the ilc contained retrogradely transported tracer .
the injection in experiment r676 was placed more laterally in the rostral ventrolateral medulla .
retrogradely labelled neurons were located in the mid rostrocaudal levels of the ilc , primarily in layer v , but did not extend caudally into the posterior portions of the ilc .
In experiment R668 the injection was placed dorsomedial to the nucleus ambiguus and included this cell group.
this resulted in retrograde filling of cells in the posterior portions of the ilc and the dorsal peduncular cortex in layers i11 and v .
spinal cord .
large injections of wga - hrp were placed between t1 and t2 in the spinal cords of 6 animals ( r394 , r401 , r406 , r415 , r417 , r421 ) .
these injections resulted in the retrograde labelling of a large population of neurons in the superficial portion of layer v in the anterior cingulate cortex and the prelimbic cortex .
rostrally , this population was continuous with a small number of neurons located ventrally in layer v of the ilc ( fig . 15a ) .
at caudal levels , the band of retrogradely labelled neurons withdrew into the medial precentral cortex and was not in continuity with the small cluster of labelled neurons in the ilc ( fig . 15b ) .
The projection from the medial prefrontal cortex to the spinal cord was bilateral with a contralateral predominance.

Discussion.S: DISCUSSION
Our results indicate that the infralimbic cortex has extensive projections to key autonomic cell groups throughout the central nervous system as well as to several limbic structures (Fig. 16).

Furthermore, there is considerable topographical organization of the projections both between the ILC and the other subdivisions of the medial frontal cortex as well as between different layers of the ILC (see Table I).
Telencephalic projections of the ILC
Re-examination of material previously reported from this laboratory (e.g., experiment R19; cf.
Fig. 2A in Saper, 82b) demonstrated that most of the medial prefrontal cells retrogradely labelled from the insular cortex are actually just beyond the border of the ILC, in the prelimbic cortex.

Those cells in the ILC that do project to the insular cortex appear to avoid the granular and dysgranular part of insular cortex, which contains a topographically organized visceral sensory map (Cechetto and Saper, 87), and instead innervate the adjacent agranular insular cortex.
Electrical or chemical stimulation of the insular cortex demonstrates that autonomic responses are mainly elicited from sites in the agranular field (Yasui et al., 90).
Injections of PHA-L into these physiologically characterized sites demonstrates that they in turn project to a variety of limbic and autonomic areas (Yasui et al., 90).
Hence the ILC appears to project to the part of the insular cortex providing outflow to limbic and autonomic structures.

Beckstead ( 79), van der Kooy ( 84), and Room et al. ( 85) previously reported that the medial subdivision of the central nucleus of the amygdala is preferentially innervated by the medial prefrontal cortex.

We find that this projection arises exclusively from the ILC; varicosities observed along the lengths of labelled fibers indicate that the medial subdivision of the central nucleus may be an important terminal field of the ILC.
The central nucleus of the amygdala is thought to play an influential role in cardiovascular regulation.

This region has extensive interconnections with the parabrachial nucleus (Moga and Gray, 85; Moga et al., 89) as well as the dorsal vagal complex (Schwaber et al., 82; van der Kooy et al., 84; Gray and Magnusson, 87).
Central nucleus efferents interact with baroreceptor derents in the nucleus of the solitary tract allowing the central nucleus to set the gain of the reflex (Pascoe et al. 89).
Hence, its projection to the central nucleus may allow the ILC to play an important role in modulating cardiovascular function.
We identified a diffuse projection to the rostra1 amygdala from the ILC, which includes the medial and cortical nuclei.
Room et al. ( 85) reported a less extensive projection from the ILC to the medial nucleus of the amygdala.

The medial nucleus of the amygdala receives indirect input from the main olfactory bulb and direct projections from the accessory olfactory bulb and has been implicated in the olfactory control of copulatory behavior in male hamsters (Lehman and Winans, 80; Maragos et al., 89).
The current series of experiments also demonstrates a projection from the ILC to the lateral subdivision of the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis.
In addition, a smaller projection to this area from the prelimbic cortex was seen in experiment R767.

Room et al. ( 85) described a projection to the bed nucleus only following the largest of their tritiated amino acid injections; those injections that were restricted to the prelimbic area did not label fibers within the bed nucleus.

Several investigators (de Olmos, '85; Moga et al., '89) have argued that the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis and the central nucleus of the amygdala may be analogous structures based on cytoarchitectural, histochemical, and connectional criteria.

Like the central nucleus, the bed nucleus has extensive connections with cell groups related to autonomic regulation such as the parabrachial nucleus, the nucleus of the solitary tract, and the paraventricular nucleus of the hypothalamus (for review, see Moga et al., '89).

Yasui et al. ('90) found that the lateral subdivision of the bed nucleus is selectively innervated by a pressor site in the insular cortex suggesting that this nucleus may play a role in cardiovascular regulation.
Thalamic projections of the ILC
The current series of experiments indicates that the ILC projects to the paratenial, paraventricular and reuniens nuclei of the thalamus.
In addition, there is dense innervation of the border zone located between the paraventricular and mediodorsal nuclei.

In contrast, the prelimbic cortex shares with the ILC an equally dense efferent projection to the paratenial nucleus, but its innervation of the paraventricular and reuniens nuclei is sparser than that derived from the ILC.

The prelimbic cortex also innervates the paraventricularJmediodorsal border zone densely, but the center of this innervation is shifted dorsolaterally relative to the terminal field occupied by ILC efferents (see A vs.
B in Fig. 5).
We also confirmed that the prelimbic cortex innervates the medial portion of the mediodorsal nucleus.
Herkenham ('78) and Room et al. ('85) had previously reported the innervation of the reuniens nucleus by the ILC.

In contrast to the current series of experiments, however, Room and coworkers also found a small number of efferents that they attributed to the ILC within the anteromedial and mediodorsal nuclei of the thalamus in the cat.
These investigators also reported that the prelimbic cortex projects to the anteromedial, reticular, and submedial thalamic nuclei as well as to the medial portion of the nucleus lateralis posterior.

Based on our combined anterograde and retrograde data, we suspect that the more extensive thalamic innervation reported by Room et al. ('85) may be attributed either to a species difference or to the large size of their injection sites overlapping several cortical fields.
For example, we demonstrated a substantial projection to the submedial nucleus of the thalamus that originates exclusively from the dorsal peduncular cortex in the rat.
Neither that ILC nor the prelimbic cortex appears to contribute to the cortical innervation of this thalamic nucleus in the rat.
Groenewegen ('88) reported that the ILC specifically projects to the medial portion of the mediodorsal nucleus.

Our data indicate that in the rat the ILC terminal field begins along the medial border of the mediodorsal nucleus and extends from this region into the paraventricular nucleus of the thalamus and rostrally into the paratenial nucleus.
This discrepancy may reflect differences in criteria used to define the borders of these nuclei.
Hypothalamic projections of the ILC
The densest terminal field of ILC efferents in the hypothalamus is within the tuberal and posterior lateral hypothalamic area.
This finding confirms and extends an earlier report by Hosoya and Matsushita ('80), which identified a projection from the ILC to the lateral hypothalamus using retrograde transport.
Though not discussed in the text of their work, the illustrations provided by Room et al. ('85) indicate that a similar projection may exist in the cat.
Injections of PHA-L placed into the prelimbic cortex resulted in a sparse distribution of labelled fibers within the lateral hypothalamus.

Injections of PHA-L into the dorsal peduncular cortex resulted in labelled fibers of medium caliber with boutons along their lengths within the anterior and tuberal portions of the lateral hypothalamus.

The ILC innervation of the tuberal and posterior lateral hypothalamic areas includes regions projecting both rostrally to the cerebral cortex and caudally to autonomic control sites such as the periaqueductal gray matter, the parabrachial nucleus, the nucleus of the solitary tract, the rostra1 ventrolateral medulla, and the preganglionic neurons of the medulla and spinal cord (Saper et al., '76, '79, '85; Hosoya and Matsushita, '80; Moga et al., '90).

Lesions of the lateral hypothalamic area can produce a profound and long-lasting somnolescence in both experimental animals and humans, suggesting that this region may play a role in mediating cortical arousal (see Saper, '85 for review).
The projection from the ILC may therefore influence the ascending arousal system, as well as descending pathways involved in autonomic control.

The projections from the insular cortex to the lateral hypothalamus overlap with those from the ILC, particularly in regions just medial to the internal capsule adjacent to the tuberomamillary nucleus Cyasui et al., '90).

Cechetto and Chen ('89) have demonstrated that cobalt blockade of synaptic transmission within the lateral hypothalamic area is capable of blocking the cardiovascular responses evoked from the insular cortex.
Whether this may be true of the cardiovascular responses evoked from the ILC remains to be demonstrated experimentally.
The infralimbic cortex innervates the supramamillary nucleus as part of a topographically organized projection from the medial prefrontal cortex to the mamillary body.

The prelimbic and infralimbic areas project to the supramamillary nucleus, whereas the dorsal peduncular cortex projects to an immediately ventral region along the dorsal surface of the medial mamillary nucleus.

The innervation of the median part of the medial mamillary nucleus observed in experiment R651 was probably due to inclusion of the tenia tecta in the injection site, since selective PHA-L injections placed in each of the other cortical fields failed to label fibers in this region of the mamillary body.
Two recent reports have also identified a projection from the medial prefrontal cortex to the mammillary body.

Allen and Hopkins ('89) made large injections of WGA-HRP into the medial prefrontal cortex and reported a pattern of anterograde labelling in the mammillary body identical to that described in the current report for experiment R651.
In addition, these investigators placed injections into the medial mammillary body and retrogradely labelled the neurons within medial prefrontal cortex.
From their figures, it appears that the dorsal peduncular cortex contained the largest number of retrogradely labelled neurons in their experiments.
Shibata ('89) also made injections of WGAHRP into an area identified as the ILC and reported a projection to the mammillary body similar to the one described here.
The supramammillary nucleus in Shibata's experiments contained less label than we would expect, suggesting that their injections were probably centered in the dorsal peduncular cortex.
Meibach and Siegal ('75) described a topographic projection to the mamillary body from the subiculum.

Using WGA-HRP injected into various subdivisions of the mamillary body, these investigators found that the anterior portion of the dorsal subiculum projects to the medial part of the medial mamillary nucleus, whereas the ventral subiculum projects to the ventromedial mamillary body.

Our current findings are consistent with the view that the dorsal tenia tecta, or anterior hippocampal rudiment, is closely related to the hippocampus in terms of general organization, cellular morphology, and connections (Haberly and Price, '78a,b; Wyss and Sripanidkulchai, '83).
By analogy, our data raise the possibility that the dorsal peduncular cortex may be related to the subiculum in a manner similar to the relationship between the tenia tecta and the hippocampus.

Other hypothalamic structures that receive a sparser projection from the ILC include the anteroventral periventricular nucleus, most of the periventricular hypothalamus throughout its rostrocaudal length, the medial preoptic area as well as the dorsomedial nucleus.
The latter two terminal fields were also observed by Room et al. ('85) in the cat.

The periventricular and preoptic terminal fields include areas important for endocrine-autonomic integration particularly in control of fluid-electrolyte homeostasis, thermoregulation, and reproduction (Simerly and Swanson, '88).

The dorsomedial nucleus, like the lateral hypothalamic area, contributes projections to many central autonomic control sites, emphasizing the role of the ILC in autonomic regulation (Saper et al., '76; ter Horst and Luiten, '86).
Mesencephalic projections of the ILC
We found a projection from the ILC to the ventrolateral quadrant of theperiaqueductat gray matter as well as from the prelimbic cortex to the dorsolateral quadrant.
