Although a number of investigators have reported a projection from the medial prefrontal cortex to the periaqueductal gray matter (Hardy and Leichnitz, '81; Room et al., '85; Neafsey et al., '86), only Wyss and Sripanidkulchai ('84) and Shipley et al. ('89) recognized the topographic organization of the projection.
However, they did not specifically attribute the innervation of the ventrolateral periaqueductal gray matter to the ILC.

The ventrolateral periaqueductal gray matter also receives afferents from the paraventricular nucleus of the hypothalamus, the lateral hypothalamic area (Saper et al., '76; ter Horst and Luitten, '86), the parabrachial nucleus (Saper and Loewy, '80), and the nucleus of the solitary tract (Ricardo and Koh, '78; Herbert et al., '89).
Several studies have implicated the ventrolateral quadrant of the periaqueductal gray matter in cardiovascular regulation.

Lesions of this area in rats can cause pronounced hypotension (Ward and Darlington, '871, whereas application of glutamate to the rostral lateral periaqueductal gray matter in cats causes hypertension and vasoconstriction of both the iliac and renal arteries in cats (Carrive et al., '89).
Application of glutamate to the caudal dorsolateral periaqueductal gray matter also produces an increase resistance in the renal arteries, whereas resistance is reduced in the iliace artery.
Carrive and colleagues have likened these hemodynamic changes to those during "threat display" and "escape" behaviors respectively.

Both Carrive et al. ('89) and Aston-Jones et al. ('89) have indicated that various subfields of the periaqueductal gray matter project to the ventrolateral medulla in a topographic pattern that may subserve the various cardiovascular responses evoked by stimulation of the periaqueductal gray matter.
The topographic innervation of the periaqueductal gray matter may thus allow the different fields of the medial prefrontal cortex to modulate specific autonomic responses.
Parabrachial nucleus projection from the ILC

In agreement with earlier reports from this laboratory (Saper, '82a; Moga et al., 'go), we found an extensive projection to the parabrachial complex from the ILC, subtending the dorsal, central, ventral, medial, and external lateral subnuclei.
A similar projection in the cat has been described by Room et al. ('85) and Yasui et al. ('85), although the subnuclear organization of ILC fibers within the parabrachial complex was not identified.

Electrical or chemical stimulation of the dorsal, central, or external lateral parabrachial subnuclei can produce cardiovascular responses (Chamberlin and Saper, '901, and hence may play a role in mediating the cardiovascular responses evoked from the ILC.
The medial and ventrolateral parabrachial subnuclei project diffusely to the insular, lateral prefrontal, and medial prefrontal cortex (Saper, '82a; Fulwiler and Saper, '84).
The ILC projection to these subnuclei may modulate cortical responses to visceral stimuli.
Medullary projections of the ILC
The ILC and the prelimbic cortex project throughout the nucleus ambiguus complex.

The compact part of the nucleus ambiguus contains motor neurons which project to all levels of the esophagus; the semicompact formation innervates the pharyngeal constrictures and cricothyroid muscle; and the loose formation innervates the intrinsic laryngeal musculature (except for the cricothyroid muscle; Bieger and Hopkins, '87).

In addition, we also found that the ILC projects to the external formation of the nucleus ambiguus, a region that innervates the heart (Bieger and Hopkins, '87)' and to the dorsal motor nucleus of the vagus nerve, which primarily innervates the gastrointestinal tract (Fox and Powley, '85; Shapiro and Miselis, '85).

The current series of experiments confirms previous reports of a bilateral projection from the medial prefrontal cortex to the nucleus of the solitary tract (Ross et al., '81; van der Kooy, '82; Terreberry et al., '83).
We demonstrated that a projection from cells in both the ventral prelimbic cortex and the ILC reaches the medial and commissural subdivisions of the nucleus of the solitary tract.
The ILC sends fibers through the ventolateral portion of the nucleus of the solitary tract, but very few synaptic contacts appear to be made there.
The ILC may therefore influence ascending visceral sensory information relayed through the nucleus of the solitary tract, and hence visceral motor responses.
We also found a direct projection from the ILC to the rostral ventrolateral medulla, confirming an earlier report by van Bockstaele et al. ('89).
The rostral ventrolateral medulla is a key area in modulating cardiovascular and respiratory activity (Ross et al., '84).

The direct innervation of both the nucleus of the solitary tract and the ventrolateral medulla by the ILC may allow coordination of resting arterial pressure as well as cardiopulmonary reflexes with ongoing behavior and emotional state.
Spinal cord projections of the ILC
The most surprising result to emerge from the current study is that the ILC projects directly to the spinal cord via the pyramidal tract.
This projection was clearly labelled by anterograde and retrograde transport of WGA-HRP.

In our PHA-L material, even with survival times of 3 to 4 weeks, labelled fibers could be followed from the ILC into the corticospinal tract and lateral funiculus of the upper cervical spinal cord, but not to their terminations.
With longer survival times of 5 weeks, labelled fibers became difficult to visualize at all.

This is consistent with a recent report from Wouterlood et al. ('90) in which they describe a gradual degradation of PHA-L terminal labeling beginning about 5 weeks postinjection and extending to 11 weeks postinjection, at which time labelled terminals were no longer demonstrable.
It is unlikely that the WGA-HRP axonal labeling is the result of transynaptic transport since the injections made were small (3-10 nl of 1% solution) and survival time short (48 hours).
In addition, the spinal cord injections at the upper thoracic level demonstrated retrograde labeling of ILC neurons.

PHA-L fibers from the medial prefrontal cortex descend through the upper cervical segments in both the dorsal lateral funiculus and in the base of the dorsal column, which contains the corticospinal tract in the rat.
In WGAHRP material, labelled fibers could be followed through these pathways as far caudally as the sacral levels of the cord.
Labelled fibers innervated lamina I of the entire spinal dorsal horn and were seen among the sympathetic preganglionic neurons of spinal lamina X and the intermediolateral cell column (Fig. 14B).
Without electron microscopic evidence, it is not possible to determine whether these fibers actually synapse upon preganglionic neurons.

An earlier report indicated the existence of a projection from the medial prefrontal cortex to the spinal cord in the rat (Miller, '87), but did not identify the cytoarchitectonic fields from which the projection arose or the sites in which it terminated.
Our data indicate that in addition to a prominent spinal projection from the prelimbic cortex, a separate, smaller projection also arises from neurons within the ILC.
Furthermore, the ILC appears to be exclusively responsible for the innervation of the sympathetic preganglionic column.
Lamina I of the spinal dorsal horn receives noiciceptive, thermal and visceral primary afferents (Perl, '84).

In addition, a number of autonomic structures in the central nervous system project to lamina I, including the paraventricular nucleus of the hypothalamus (Swanson and Kuypers, '80; Sawchenko and Swanson, '82; Swanson et al., '82), the Edinger-Westphal nucleus (Loewy and Saper, '781, and the parabrachial complex (Holstege and Kuypers, '82).
Lamina I cells project to the lateral hypothalamic area (Burnstein et al., '871, the parabrachial complex (Cechetto et al., '85), the ventrolateral medulla (R.M.
Slugg and A.R.
Light, personal communication), and the nucleus of the solitary tract (Menetrey and Basbaum, '87).
Thus the projection from the ILC to lamina I of the spinal cord may modulate nociceptive and visceral sensory afferents which play a role in autonomic regulation.

The direct projection from the ILC to the preganglionic parasympathetic and sympathetic cell groups in the medulla and spinal cord is remarkable, as no other motor neuronal group is thought to receive direct cortical innervation in nonprimates.

If a monosynaptic projection from the ILC to preganglionic neurons can be established with electron microscopy, the concept of the ILC as a visceral motor cortex exerting direct autonomic control would be greatly strengthened.
